newsitem.title: NORWAY: Oslo hopes longer trading hours mean more money.
newsitem.headline: Oslo hopes longer trading hours mean more money.

text.p: The Oslo Bourse will extend trading hours by one hour from March 3 in the hope of attracting more foreign investors.

Bourse director Kjell Froensdal, explaining the decision in a speech on Thursday night, said the bourse was worried it was losing business to the Stockholm, London and New York exchanges by closing at 4 p.m. (1500 GMT) -- a time when the competing markets are open for trading.

The Norwegian stock exchange, one of the smallest in Europe, recently decided to extend opening hours by one hour to 5 p.m.(1600 GMT). Simultaneously, bond market dealing will be extended by one hour to 4 p.m.
The decision was made over the objections of brokers, who complain about long hours already. The bourse opens at 10 a.m. (0900 GMT).
"We hear what the brokers say, but we want to try something," Froensdal said. "If we don't improve business we won't keep people in the office for an extra hour."
Big Norwegian companies such as Norsk Hydro ASA and Kvaerner ASA are traded on several foreign bourses as well as in Oslo.
Froensdal said it was important to stay tuned to the needs of foreign investors.
"We are a marginal market to many foreign investors," Froensdal said. "They can leave here, but if they left the British or American markets they might as well drop out of stocks entirely."
Foreign investments, including British and U.S. pension funds, now represent about 35 percent of the market value of Norway's bourse stock, up from 21 percent 10 years ago.

Froensdal stressed the need for closer cooperation between the Nordic stock exchanges to increase economy and enhance foreign investors' focus on Oslo as well as on Stockholm, Helsinki and Copenhagen.
"So why would we need a joint Nordic bourse?" he asked. "We are doing fine here in Oslo.
"But investors are looking for liquidity. It is also becoming more and more expensive for a small bourse like the one in Oslo to keep up with technological development."

He said the Oslo Bourse had been a pioneer in promoting cross-border trading in equity derivatives. A year ago the bourse and the Norwegian Futures and Options Clearing House agreed to set up a link with the Swedish derivatives exchange OM and its London equivalent OMLX.
"We have a good record (in cooperation)," Froensdal said.

The system, under which foreigners will be able to trade in Oslo derivatives via London and Stockholm, goes into operation on February 14. Oslo handles only 6,000 contracts a day to make it one of Europe's smallest derivatives markets.
